**INSTITUTION PALLIATIVE CARE CONSULTATION PATIENT NAME: **NAME[AAA, BBB M] ACCOUNT #: **ID-NUM **ROOM ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[YYY M ZZZ] CONSULTING PHYSICIAN: **NAME[UUU M VVV] DATE OF ADMISSION: **DATE[Jun 08 2006] DATE OF CONSULTATION: **DATE[Jul 23 06] REASON FOR CONSULTATION: The patient is a **AGE[in 70s]-year-old, Caucasian female we were asked to see to provide support for her husband and daughters. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: She was originally admitted to **INSTITUTION from the outpatient dialysis unit when she developed fever and hypotension. She required intubation. She then was taken to surgery immediately for bleeding lacerated liver. Final pathology revealed primary amyloidosis. Since admission, she has had a complicated course with sepsis, continued respiratory failure, renal failure, recurrent GI bleeding, anasarca, malnutrition, and coma. We met with her husband, **NAME[TTT], who had a kidney transplant approximately eight years ago and also had a rocky course, and he said that he was in the hospital for 102 days. He said **NAME[BBB], his wife, never gave up on him, and he is not going "give up on her." PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Diabetes mellitus. 2. Renal failure. 3. Osteoporosis. 4. Hypertension. 5. Coronary artery disease. 6. Hypercholesterolemia. MEDICATIONS: Noted in the chart. ALLERGIES: CIPRO. SOCIAL HISTORY: The patient has two grown daughters, one is an attorney and one is a pharmacist, who is going to be coming in later. No alcohol or tobacco. The patient is Catholic. She is _____. Will continue to ask the priest to come and see them. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is unresponsive on the ventilator. She does not respond to voice or touch. The nurses say she does open her eyes. Her pupils are equally reactive to light and accommodation. She does not focus. She does not track or ____ to eyes. She is very jaundiced. Mouth has no lesions. Lungs have decreased breath sounds with some crackles in the bases. Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen is distended. She has multiple packing that she dehisced from most of her wounds in her abdomen. She has 4+ anasarca to her mid abdomen. She has open wounds on her legs and has redness on her bottom, but no decubitus. I could not get her to follow voice or any commands. The nurse practitioner got her to open her eyes for voice. LABORATORY DATA: Her laboratory data is as reviewed.
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: No symptoms at this time. The major issue is negotiating with the husband. We will try to meet with the family. It sounds like he is under quite an amount of stress. He clearly believes and hopes that if he can only be there for his wife that she will get better. ___________________________________ **NAME[WWW M.
